intro: Acanthopale labordei, commonly known as the Laborde's acanthopale, is a rare flowering plant native to specific regions of southern Africa. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads composed of both ray and disk flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and is adapted to arid or semi-arid environments. Its leaves are usually narrow and covered in fine hairs, while its flowers display a range of colors from yellow to orange. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a species of conservation concern.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acanthopale labordei is primarily native to the arid regions of southern Africa, specifically Namibia and South Africa. It is commonly found in the Namib Desert and the Succulent Karoo biome. This plant thrives in rocky outcrops and sandy soils where it can receive limited water. It is well adapted to the harsh, dry conditions of its native habitat. Due to its unique adaptations, it is considered an important component of the local flora.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acanthopale labordei was mainly introduced to areas with disturbed soils and human-altered landscapes. It thrives in environments with moderate to high light exposure and well-drained soil. This plant is often found in roadsides, abandoned fields, and along urban perimeters. Its introduction has led to its spread in several regions beyond its native range. It is considered an invasive species in some areas due to its rapid growth and competitive nature.
